Rationale
This module is introduced as part of the School of Life Sciences curriculum review. It integrates material from the (discontinued) module PHAR427 but with updated content and assessment strategies, as response to student feedback.

Overview

Overview
Skill/Other Attribute 1:

Lifelong learning skills

How this is developed:
"Self-directed learning"
Educational Aims
To provide students with the opportunity to develop advanced knowledge and understanding of cardiovascular and respiratory pharmacology;

To develop in students an awareness of how dysfunction in these systems can be treated with current drugs, and how improved understanding can lead to improved drugs;

To raise awareness of th e specific problems associated with drug side-effects in the cardiovascular system, and the approaches taken to test for these in drug development.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The aim of this module is to develop advanced knowledge and understanding of cardiovascular and respiratory pharmacology. It will develop an awareness of the basic pathophysiology of major cardiovascular and respiratory diseases. It will also explain the mechanisms of action of drugs at the molecular, cellular, organ, and system levels in health and disease. The module is taught through short asynchronous course content delivery and face to face tutorial and revision sessions held in person in lecture theatres. It will be assessed with continuous assessments.
Outline Syllabus
Atherosclerosis and lipid lowering therapy;

Anticoagulants;

Antithrombotics;

Pharmacogenetics of cardiovascular medicine;

Clinical pharmacology of heart failure: pathophysiology and treatment;

Treatment of hypertension;

Treatment of ischaemic heart disease;

Cardiac ion channels and action potentials;

Mechanism of arrhythmia and antiarrhythmic drugs (including QT Prolongation and Torsades de Pointes);

Vascular pharmacology and diseases affecting the vascular system;

Adverse effects of the drugs on the heart and vascular system: cardiovascular toxicity;

The normal lung and in-vivo dynamic testing of lung function;

Asthma;

Chronic airflow limitation;

Drug-induced pulmonary dysfunction – molecular mechanisms and pathophysiology;

Drug-induced pulmonary dysfunction – issues in clinical prediction, identification and treatment.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Delivery methods may include PBL, flipped classrooms, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Lecture content, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Teaching method 1:
Asynchronous online lecture material with follow up synchronous face to face or online tutorial/question and answer discussion sessions.

•The course has been structured so that the content will be released as short pre-recorded “concept” video explanations broken down into topics that would normally be covered in a synchronous lecture. Due to the number of students on this and the sister Life401 course, this asynchronous content will be released on a Monday afternoon. The following Monday morning (in the already arranged 2-hour lecture slot) the time will be split into the opportunity for 4 face to face sessions for 25 students for 25-minute duration. One of these sessions will be via zoom for students not able to attend face to face. These sessions will require the students to book one of the available slots in the lecture theatre. The lecturer who provided the course content released that week will then be available to answer questions emailed to the lecturer prior to the session, or to take some limited spontaneous questions.

•In addition, there will be some zoom revision sessions for all students to attend.

Teaching method 2:
Self-directed learning aided by directed reading and formative questions

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Students complete two pieces of extended writing. Specifically, these assessments enhance digital fluency in our students, a skill highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their field. These authentic assessments are research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning

Assessment 1 will be a 1000 word written assignment. This will be worth 40% and occur following the first cycle of teaching.

Assessment 2 will be a 1500 word written assignment. This will be worth 60% and occur at the end of the course.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Rationale
This module is introduced as part of the School of Life Sciences curriculum review. It integrates material from the (discontinued) module PHAR427 but with updated content and assessment strategies, as response to student feedback.

Overview

Overview
Skill/Other Attribute 1:

"

"
Lifelong learning skills

How this is developed:
"Self-directed learning"
Educational Aims
To provide students with the opportunity to develop advanced knowledge and understanding of cardiovascular and respiratory pharmacology;

To develop in students an awareness of how dysfunction in these systems can be treated with current drugs, and how improved understanding can lead to improved drugs;

To raise awareness of th e specific problems associated with drug side-effects in the cardiovascular system, and the approaches taken to test for these in drug development.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The aim of this module is to develop advanced knowledge and understanding of cardiovascular and respiratory pharmacology. It will develop an awareness of the basic pathophysiology of major cardiovascular and respiratory diseases. It will also explain the mechanisms of action of drugs at the molecular, cellular, organ, and system levels in health and disease. The module is taught through short asynchronous course content delivery and face to face tutorial and revision sessions held in person in lecture theatres. It will be assessed with continuous assessments.
Outline Syllabus
Atherosclerosis and lipid lowering therapy;

Anticoagulants;

Antithrombotics;

Pharmacogenetics of cardiovascular medicine;

Clinical pharmacology of heart failure: pathophysiology and treatment;

Treatment of hypertension;

Treatment of ischaemic heart disease;

Cardiac ion channels and action potentials;

Mechanism of arrhythmia and antiarrhythmic drugs (including QT Prolongation and Torsades de Pointes);

Vascular pharmacology and diseases affecting the vascular system;

Adverse effects of the drugs on the heart and vascular system: cardiovascular toxicity;

The normal lung and in-vivo dynamic testing of lung function;

Asthma;

Chronic airflow limitation;

Drug-induced pulmonary dysfunction – molecular mechanisms and pathophysiology;

Drug-induced pulmonary dysfunction – issues in clinical prediction, identification and treatment.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Delivery methods may include PBL, flipped classrooms, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Lecture content, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Teaching method 1:
Asynchronous online lecture material with follow up synchronous face to face or online tutorial/question and answer discussion sessions.

•The course has been structured so that the content will be released as short pre-recorded “concept” video explanations broken down into topics that would normally be covered in a synchronous lecture. Due to the number of students on this and the sister Life401 course, this asynchronous content will be released on a Monday afternoon. The following Monday morning (in the already arranged 2-hour lecture slot) the time will be split into the opportunity for 4 face to face sessions for 25 students for 25-minute duration. One of these sessions will be via zoom for students not able to attend face to face. These sessions will require the students to book one of the available slots in the lecture theatre. The lecturer who provided the course content released that week will then be available to answer questions emailed to the lecturer prior to the session, or to take some limited spontaneous questions.

•In addition, there will be some zoom revision sessions for all students to attend.

Teaching method 2:
Self-directed learning aided by directed reading and formative questions

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Students complete two pieces of extended writing. Specifically, these assessments enhance digital fluency in our students, a skill highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their field. These authentic assessments are research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning

Assessment 1 will be a 1000 word written assignment. This will be worth 40% and occur following the first cycle of teaching.

Assessment 2 will be a 1500 word written assignment. This will be worth 60% and occur at the end of the course.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

 LO3 ​​​​To discuss the latest understanding of principles underlying the development of new drugs for the treatment of cardiovascular and respiratory diseases.

Rationale
This module is introduced as part of the School of Life Sciences curriculum review. It integrates material from the (discontinued) module PHAR427 but with updated content and assessment strategies, as response to student feedback.

Overview

Overview
Skill/Other Attribute 1:

Lifelong learning skills

Educational Aims
To provide students with the opportunity to develop advanced knowledge and understanding of cardiovascular and respiratory pharmacology;

To develop in students an awareness of how dysfunction in these systems can be treated with current drugs, and how improved understanding can lead to improved drugs;

To raise awareness of th e specific problems associated with drug side-effects in the cardiovascular system, and the approaches taken to test for these in drug development.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The aim of this module is to develop advanced knowledge and understanding of cardiovascular and respiratory pharmacology. It will develop an awareness of the basic pathophysiology of major cardiovascular and respiratory diseases. It will also explain the mechanisms of action of drugs at the molecular, cellular, organ, and system levels in health and disease. The module is taught through short asynchronous course content delivery and face to face tutorial and revision sessions held in person in lecture theatres. It will be assessed with continuous assessments.
Outline Syllabus
Atherosclerosis and lipid lowering therapy;

Anticoagulants;

Antithrombotics;

Pharmacogenetics of cardiovascular medicine;

Clinical pharmacology of heart failure: pathophysiology and treatment;

Treatment of hypertension;

Treatment of ischaemic heart disease;

Cardiac ion channels and action potentials;

Mechanism of arrhythmia and antiarrhythmic drugs (including QT Prolongation and Torsades de Pointes);

Vascular pharmacology and diseases affecting the vascular system;

Adverse effects of the drugs on the heart and vascular system: cardiovascular toxicity;

The normal lung and in-vivo dynamic testing of lung function;

Asthma;

Chronic airflow limitation;

Drug-induced pulmonary dysfunction – molecular mechanisms and pathophysiology;

Drug-induced pulmonary dysfunction – issues in clinical prediction, identification and treatment.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Delivery methods may include PBL, flipped classrooms, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Lecture content, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Teaching method 1:
Asynchronous online lecture material with follow up synchronous face to face or online tutorial/question and answer discussion sessions.

•The course has been structured so that the content will be released as short pre-recorded “concept” video explanations broken down into topics that would normally be covered in a synchronous lecture. Due to the number of students on this and the sister Life401 course, this asynchronous content will be released on a Monday afternoon. The following Monday morning (in the already arranged 2-hour lecture slot) the time will be split into the opportunity for 4 face to face sessions for 25 students for 25-minute duration. One of these sessions will be via zoom for students not able to attend face to face. These sessions will require the students to book one of the available slots in the lecture theatre. The lecturer who provided the course content released that week will then be available to answer questions emailed to the lecturer prior to the session, or to take some limited spontaneous questions.

•In addition, there will be some zoom revision sessions for all students to attend.

Teaching method 2:
Self-directed learning aided by directed reading and formative questions

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Students complete two pieces of extended writing. Specifically, these assessments enhance digital fluency in our students, a skill highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their field. These authentic assessments are research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning

Assessment 1 will be a 1000 word written assignment. This will be worth 40% and occur following the first cycle of teaching.

Assessment 2 will be a 1500 word written assignment. This will be worth 60% and occur at the end of the course.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

 LO3 ​​​​To discuss the latest understanding of principles underlying the development of new drugs for the treatment of cardiovascular and respiratory diseases.
